description.narrative: By end 2017, at least 70% of children especially those living in areas of difficult access, receive adequate health care for priority diseases, including malaria, acute respiratory infections (ARI) and diarrheal diseases including in emergency situations and at least 50% of households know and adopt the Essential health Family Practices with involvement of men and an increased participation of women in health care decisions, which contributes to Child Health, Maternal And Newborn Health. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By the end of 2017, women, children, especially the most vulnerable have access to and utilize high-impact health interventions and communities know and adopt the Essential Family Practices of Health to reduce maternal and infant mortality including by emergency situations

description.narrative: UNICEF support to provision of essential and critical medicines in all health facilities and to increase the capacity of service providers (including CHWs) in the delivery of quality integrated community-based services through adequate training has helped to adequately treat sick children suffering from diarrhea or pneumonia, even in remote areas. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:14/12/2017
